William.Action: Provides a note to soldiers to facilitate secure transaction of bags, indicating forethought and coordination.
Approaches the soldiers in a friendly manner, provides clear answers to their questions, and ensures his man Todd helps with the horses
Taps Todd roughly on the shoulder
Slides off his horse, lands on his feet, secures horses calmly and confidently.
Responds to suspicious questions smoothly, defuses tension.
Taps Todd roughly on the shoulder to give an order, suggesting confident command.
Mentions having no lieutenant but refers to Cap’ain Louison, showing situational awareness.
Decides not to wait despite warnings and moves towards the bank confidently with his men.
Nods to Todd to kill the approaching threat; coordinates an attack effectively.
Leads the group in a well-executed violent bank takeover, successfully neutralizing armed guards.
Stabs a wounded soldier to death instead of allowing a slower, possibly more painful death or mercy killing; orders the killing of the elderly teller.
Smiles and kisses Annabelle after the violence.
Flinches and looks away from the injured small boy with blood on his face and neck after the shooting.
Calculates the danger ahead and acknowledges Sam’s injury with concern.
Tries to reassure Sam by downplaying injury and promising to get the bullet out later.
Turns away and urges horse on faster instead of continuing to express concern or comfort.
Quietly converses with Annabelle and shares a personal story about a fellow soldier he bonded with.
Makes a flirty comment about a nurse but is ignored; does not press Annabelle further.
Assesses Sam's wound calmly and determines it's not too serious, plans to remove the bullet later.
Leads group confidently by knowing the route ahead and estimating travel times.
Offers a place to stay to anyone who wants it, showing a willingness to share.
Plans to use the name of a deceased acquaintance to seek hospitality, but threatens that if hospitality is not extended, 'we’ll have to take care of them either way.'
Admits he may have killed a kid and asks Annabelle to keep it a secret from others.
Speaks quietly and calmly with Annabelle, showing concern about the group's safety by instructing them to move slowly and carefully.
Politely tries to get the old man's attention and asks for directions, despite the old man's brusque responses.
Expresses surprise when the old man claims not to know the farm, but does not react with hostility or rudeness.
Asks Sam to light the lantern in a dark area, enabling better visibility.
Politely addresses the old man to ask for directions to the Hollister place.
Attempts to clarify with the old man when he gives an unhelpful answer.
Appears somewhat surprised and doubtful when the old man denies knowledge of the Hollister place despite William's prior expectations.
Encourages the group to keep moving forward; shows concern and caution by saying 'We'll be careful' after Annabelle reports seeing someone watching.
Wets his lips with his tongue while looking at the ominous house, indicating nervousness or apprehension but still proceeds.
Shows concern and checks on Sam after the creature runs past him.
Says 'Well, that's good news' upon realizing the creature is not breathing, showing a detached or possibly sarcastic attitude.
Receives hesitant looks from the group and then responds sardonically when no one follows him into the cornfield.
Instructs Sam to keep an eye out for more creatures before moving on, showing a sense of responsibility for the group's safety.
Shows sarcasm and annoyance toward Annabelle's fear of the scarecrow, rolling his eyes at her embarrassment.
Maintains composure and shows sarcastic humor to defuse tension about the scarecrow, encourages group to move on.
Confidently identifies and points out direction to proceed in the cornfield.
Consoles his horse by soothing it with quiet words.
Dismisses horses' strange behavior by calling them 'stupid and crazy'.
Accurately points out the direction of the house and rationalizes why the cornfields look smaller from a distance.
Takes initiative by tying his horse to a hanging branch and attempts to calm the horse.
Dismisses concerns about the horses' behavior with a blunt statement.
Stops Joseph from moving forward too quickly and points out footprints, indicating carefulness and concern for safety, showing a protective and considerate attitude.
Nods and gives a cautious instruction to be careful, demonstrating responsibility and a caring leadership approach.
Takes the lantern and leads the group into the house, notices boot prints on the dusty floor and stops Joseph from moving forward to assess the situation carefully.
Nods in agreement with Todd's suggestion but gives a cautious warning to be careful, showing leadership and prudence.
Advises Joseph not to chew on the gold coins, showing concern and gentle correction.
Agrees with Annabelle's idea of helping Sam immediately, supporting a caring action.
Lightly teases Sam about bullets bouncing off him, sharing a moment of camaraderie.
Invites Dog to come along, trying to include and engage the animal.
Derides Dog as useless when it declines, showing impatience and dismissiveness.
Warns Sam to keep a hand on his gun for safety, showing protective and prudent behavior.
Suggests getting Joseph to force the door open or chopping it down to help others potentially trapped inside, showing care about their wellbeing and sleep.
Attempts to open the door with Todd, assesses the situation calmly and suggests getting Joseph to force it or chopping it down if necessary, considers safety and rest.
Nods to Sam and inquires about his condition in a friendly manner.
Acknowledges Annabelle's update with interest, showing concern.
Supports Todd's suggestion to light the lanterns without hesitation.
Dismisses the front door creaking as 'Fucking wind,' possibly downplaying others' nervousness.
Suggests sleeping in shifts so everyone can feel safer and secure.
Nods quietly to Clyde's pragmatic comment without dismissing others' concerns.
Acknowledges the group's unease and agrees to move on at first light, showing understanding of others' discomfort.
Smiles at Sam and tells him to cheer up during a tense moment.
Tries to explore the loft despite potential danger, showing initiative and calm after falling.
Responds to Clyde's concern with reassurance ('Yeah').
After falling, brushes himself off and dismisses the danger in a frustrated but composed way, indicating resilience and not burdening others.
Kicks and further breaks the ladder in frustration.
Suggests going back inside and agrees with Annabelle's suggestion about the horses without argument.
Hands the book to Annabelle when she asks to see it.
Responds dismissively 'How should I know?' when asked about the book being a code.
Suggests they leave the barn before the storm and lets Joseph stay and play with the book inside.
Examines the book carefully and admits he cannot read it, deferring to Annabelle for a better look.
Quickly decides to leave the barn before the storm arrives, prioritizing safety over exploring the mysterious book further.
Responds with 'How should I know?' when asked about the book possibly being a code, showing limited insight or unwillingness to speculate.
Offers Annabelle to lie down and join her in a gentle kiss.
Engages in intimate and sincere interaction with Annabelle in a private setting.
Responds promptly and seriously to Sam's concern about Joseph being missing, takes initiative to get dressed quickly and go look for Joseph.
Gently wakes Annabelle to inform her about Joseph and instructs her to stay and lock the door for safety.
Leans down and kisses Annabelle after instructing her to get rest despite having a gun, showing care and tenderness.
Tries to reassure others about Dog possibly wandering off; suggests holding onto guns for safety.
Shrugs at the lack of response when calling Joseph, showing limited emotional reaction.
Expresses concern about Sam's safety after he returns from the cornfield.
Suggests holding onto guns when going out alone, showing caution and preparedness.
Shrugs and walks away after no response to calling Joseph, showing resignation rather than proactive problem-solving.
Offers a possible explanation that Joseph might be playing a joke, indicating a willingness to consider less dire possibilities.
Runs immediately to Annabelle's aid after she screams, puts an arm around her, asks if she is alright, tries to comfort her.
Leads the search to find the boy and expresses concern about the house's passageways, showing proactive involvement.
Leads the group quickly to investigate after hearing the scream, taking initiative.
Asks logical questions to assess the situation (where the boy went, possibility of windows or hidden passageways).
Comforts Annabelle to keep her calm after the frightening event.
Shows some impatience or overconfidence when he says 'they’ll find him in a second' before fully investigating.
Suggests checking walls for hidden passageways, showing problem-solving ability.
Tells Sam to lie down and rest, promising to wake him if anything comes up.
Declines to join Annabelle and Todd in looking around, insisting someone stay behind to guard the house.
Organizes the group to get rest before moving on at first light, delegates waking Sam if needed.
Assesses the situation outside (rain, environment) and decides to look around for safety or other concerns.
Insists that someone stay inside to watch for intruders rather than everyone wandering off looking around.
Questions Clyde's whereabouts upon noticing his absence, showing alertness to possible risk.
Reaches out hesitantly and touches Annabelle's arm when she is panicked, asks if she is okay.
Embraces Annabelle in the pouring rain to comfort her.
Acknowledges Annabelle's feelings and tries to ease the tension with a smile.
Shows concern for Joseph, refuses to leave him behind despite danger.
Calmly tries to reassure Annabelle despite her panic, showing measured emotional control and presence of mind in a tense situation.
Considers a plausible explanation for Joseph's disappearance instead of jumping to conclusions, demonstrating rational thinking.
Does not immediately erupt into panic or hysteria, instead choosing to comfort Annabelle, indicating emotional intelligence and confidence.
Although aware of strange events, he admits uncertainty and does not overstate his knowledge or abilities, showing honest appraisal but some lack of decisive insight.
Considers Clyde's sighting carefully, reassures others by suggesting a benign explanation (playing a game), and expresses relief that Dog might not be lost.
Questions the reliability of Clyde's sighting and cautiously evaluates the situation before concluding it's probably Joseph playing a game.
Assumes there are no bears in the area to rule out other explanations for the sighting, showing practical reasoning.
Offers to take a shift sitting so others can rest.
Proposes resting first, inviting others to join.
Suggests taking some rest and offers a plan to organize watch duties with others.
Engages practically with others and shows awareness of fatigue.
Allows Annabelle to rest her head on his shoulder and rolls a cigarette for her when she asks.
Sits down heavily on the floor and appears relaxed and comfortable, enabling a warm, intimate moment with Annabelle.
Expresses concern about leaving Annabelle alone but decides to go check on Clyde despite his worry.
Instructs Sam to watch over Annabelle while he goes after Clyde.
Runs out into the rain searching for Clyde, holding lantern aloft, showing concern and willingness to help.
Turns away from Sam abruptly and runs out without explanation, shutting the door behind him.
Runs out into the rain holding a lantern to search for Clyde, follows a trail of broken cornstalks despite poor visibility and difficult weather conditions.
Throws his arms around Annabelle when she sobs and speaks gently to her, placing hands on her shoulders to comfort her.
Shakes Sam's arm and shoulder to try to rouse him, checks for signs of life, and bows his head slightly upon realizing Sam is dead.
Shouts angrily into the cornfield searching for Clyde, showing frustration but concern.
Gives Annabelle an incredulous look and shows impatience when she talks about Jeffy.
Barely pays attention to Annabelle’s emotional revelation and responds curtly.
Leans forward to feel for a pulse on Sam, showing concern for Sam’s wellbeing.
Engages with Todd calmly and tries to understand his fear and confusion.
Steps forward and directly asks Todd about Sam, showing an attempt to communicate and find answers.
Leans forward and feels for a pulse in Sam’s neck, attempting to assess the situation physically.
Asks direct questions to gather information despite confusion, maintaining focus on the situation.
Looks incredulous and seems dismissive when Annabelle reports strange behavior, showing some skepticism.
Responds to Todd's distress calmly and tries to clarify confusing statements.
Does not act on or explore the emotional or psychological aspects of Todd’s condition beyond asking questions.
Cautiously sticks his pistol back into his waistband and holds Todd's gaze after Annabelle defends Todd, showing some restraint.
Concedes that Todd did not take the gold, despite personal doubts, reflecting a level of tolerance and fairness.
Cautiously sticks his pistol back into his waistband while still holding Todd's gaze, showing controlled and confident behavior during tense negotiation.
States that he looked for Clyde but couldn’t find him, indicating effort in a difficult situation but potential failure to secure a companion.
Displays some doubt internally (blinks and does not look entirely convinced) but manages to maintain composure outwardly.
Hurries after Todd to check on him despite tension over leaving without gold.
Engages quietly and respectfully with Todd, standing next to him in silence at the barn.
Insists on not leaving without the gold despite Todd's suggestion to abandon it for safety.
Moves to stand next to Todd and assess the horrific scene in the barn calmly after an abrupt stop and silence from Todd.
Shows concern for Todd by asking if he is alright.
Attempts to understand Todd by asking what he saw.
Looks to Annabelle for support or shared understanding.
Tries to reassure Todd and encourages him to leave the barn, showing calmness and leadership.
Looks at Annabelle and does not appear to respond to the mysterious voice or investigate the loft himself.
Expresses concern for Sam and wants to say goodbye before leaving.
Insists on staying to look for gold despite others wanting to leave and forget.
Engages seriously and openly with Annabelle and Todd, maintaining their gaze during conversation.
Insists on hope despite evidence Sam is dead, showing optimism and concern.
Expresses strong anger about the situation and desire for revenge (burn the place down).
Shares discovery of Sam’s shoe and urges group to search for him.
Leads Todd and Annabelle through the cornfield, pushing aside corn stalks to create a path.
Encourages the group to keep going despite poor visibility and signs of danger.
Keeps focus on their goal and reassures by noting they are headed in the right direction.
Pushes his way into the cornfield creating a trail for others to follow.
Locates a recently used trail by inspecting the broken cornstalk stump.
Insists on proceeding down the newly found trail despite poor visibility and others' hesitation.
Expresses uncertainty about their location but maintains confidence about the general direction.
Steps forward to investigate and cuts the ropes to free the scarecrow (Clyde) despite obvious danger, handing his lantern to Annabelle to help.
Speaks reassuringly to Clyde while cutting him loose, asking him to hold on.
Looks at Clyde’s body in shock, asks what is going on
Encourages Todd to get up and dismisses Todd's fearful claims as just the storm
Looks at Clyde’s body in shock, asks what is going on, tries to calm Todd by attributing his fear to the storm, encourages Todd to come with them.
Shouts 'Todd! No!' trying to stop Todd from killing himself.
Follows Annabelle silently when she pulls him away from Todd's body.
Urges Annabelle to slow down while struggling physically to keep up with her.
Mutely follows Annabelle without taking initiative after Todd's suicide.
Struggles to keep up, slips and falls repeatedly while trying to follow Annabelle.
Calls out to Annabelle despite difficult conditions, attempts to continue moving forward after falling.
Shouts repeatedly for Annabelle, trying to communicate and find her despite fear and confusion.
Draws his pistol and prepares to defend himself when sensing an unknown presence, showing caution but no aggression towards Annabelle.
Slows down and assesses surroundings despite being winded; looks carefully for Annabelle.
Draws his pistol and reacts cautiously to an ambiguous threat in the dark cornfield.
Calls out repeatedly but is unable to maintain direction or control in the dense cornfield.
Whispers 'Annabelle?' nervously, showing concern for her safety.
Raises and fires pistol towards scarecrow figure despite unclear threat, showing protective but fearful behavior.
Falls to his knees, sobbing hysterically after shooting the figure.
Stares blankly and aimlessly after the shooting, showing deep distress and sorrow.
Fires at the dark figure approaching him without hesitation.
Reaches out gently and touches the side of Annabelle's face, showing tenderness towards her corpse.
Immediately rises to his feet after the dog is knocked back and assesses the situation, noting the dog is nearer to the gun than him and makes a quick decision to run.
Runs limping badly through the cornfield, trying to escape Dog, though he is wounded and cannot outrun the dog.
Fails to notice that Dog has stopped snapping at his ankles and is no longer directly behind him, indicating a brief lapse in situational awareness.
Looks around the kitchen and notices details like the dirty cloth doll with a missing button eye.
Acknowledges Todd's observation about the stove not having been used recently and agrees to move on.
Reaches out to turn over a dusty picture frame to reveal a hidden family portrait, showing curiosity and engagement with his surroundings.
Calls out to Todd and reacts with visible relief upon hearing his voice, indicating concern and care for his companion.
